node.text:
This video will answer questions about raising a Highly Sensitive Child - ⁣
⁣
1:40 Q&A - How do I respond when my child cries over every little thing? ⁣
⁣
3:18 Q&A - How can you help your child name their emotions & why is this important? ⁣
⁣
4:05 Q&A - How do I help my child when they are embarrassed or ashamed? ⁣
⁣
6:33 - Q&A - How does being a Highly Sensitive Parent help? ⁣
⁣
7:30 - Q&A - My 3 year old Highly Sensitive Child hits his sister & then asks why he did it. Aren’t Highly Sensitive Children supposed to be empathetic? ⁣
⁣
9:05 - Q&A - How do you explain to other people that your child is Highly Sensitive? ⁣
⁣
10:20 - Q&A - How do I help my Highly Sensitive Child with a lack of confidence, especially socially? ⁣
⁣
12:13 Q&A - Is there anything I can do to help my child be less sensitive? ⁣
⁣
13:50 Q&A - my child has very big tantrums transitioning from daycare to home. I’ve tried everything! ⁣
⁣
16:20 Q&A - How do I deal with Highly Sensitive Teenagers? ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

node.text:
This video shares what High Sensitivity is, how you can identify it in your child, & how you can support them 💛⁣
⁣
0:35 What is high sensitivity⁣
⁣
3:13 For parents who aren’t highly sensitive themselves ⁣
⁣
6:15 Q&A - is high sensitivity genetic? ⁣
⁣
6:40 Q&A - can you see high sensitivity in newborns? ⁣
⁣
7:45 Q&A - my son is calm & controlled at school but loses it when he gets home. is this normal? ⁣
⁣
9:10 Q&A - what is Sensory Processing Disorder & how to deal with it? ⁣
⁣
12:43 Q&A - how do you deal with attention & focus issues with highly sensitive children? ⁣
⁣
14:42 Q&A - how do you build resilience in highly sensitive children? ⁣
⁣
16:10 the most important TRUTH about highly sensitive children ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

node.title: RAISING A HIGHLY SENSITIVE CHILD PT 1 //

node.text:
Here’s how to navigate your child’s behavioral issues 💛

Here’s what we covered: 

2.06 the pattern of behavioral issues in children during lockdown 

4:45 easing your parental anxiety 

5:40 for parents of children with additional needs 

7:26 how a child’s emotions connect to their behavior issues 

8:30 the BEST strategy to reduce negative behaviors with your child 

11:45 Q & A - dealing with toddler tantrums 

#ResilientLittleHearts

Due to the current situation in the world with the coronavirus, many people are experiencing fear. .
This video will share tips on how to help your children deal with fear 💛

node.title: HELPING YOUR CHILD DEAL WITH FEAR //

node.text: High sensitivity is a gift to steward within your child. Just like any gift there are strengths - tenderhearted empathy, intelligence, creativity & deep thinking. But highly sensitive individuals also typically struggle with anxiety more than the general population. Helping your highly sensitive child learn to overcome fear and anxiety is really important for their future...

node.text: Resilience is the capacity to overcome stress or challenge. It is a trait we all want to cultivate in our children. But it isn't going to just happen by itself, it is something we need to intentionally cultivate... #ResilientLittleHearts #TheBoyWhoStoodUpTall

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on August 30, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Beneath mis-behavior is often a child struggling; aware they are not meeting expectations, but often unaware, or unequipped, of how to do so. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT 4 क'.

node.text:
Despite it often seeming that they don't care, most of the time a child is acutely aware when they are not meeting expectations… & they feel poorly about it.

When this tension goes on for a long time, they will often internalize that there is something wrong with them, or that they don't measure up.

.
If you child is consistently struggling to meet expectations, there are usually a few different reasons: 

1. You have unrealistic expectations of them, for their age, stage of development or personality

2. They are struggling to process big emotions from situations they have gone through, & it's coming out through their behavior

3. They may have undiagnosed special needs and don't currently have the skill-set to meet what may be "normal" development markers

4. You have lost a connection with their heart & they are using mis-behavior as a cry for attention...

.
Whatever the situation you are currently walking through, remember they desperately want your love, acceptance & belief in them…. 💛💛💛

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on August 27, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of text that says 'Emotional health in childhood is created in the space of loving relationships. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT. i'.

node.text:
Children learn their self-regulation through their connection with safe & loving relationships 💛

Whether you are a parent, grandparent, teacher, coach, aunty, uncle, or anyone working with children… 👇🏼

Your consistency, encouragement, love & stability is laying a positive foundation for their future mental & emotional health.

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.text:
How to know if your child might be Highly Sensitive 👇🏼

High Sensitivity is a personality trait that affects 20% of the population. 

Here are some signs your child may have this trait:

💛 They are a deep thinker, & process the meaning of life

💛 They are easily frustrated or overwhelmed by loud noise, lights or temperature

💛 They are highly empathetic & tender-hearted towards others 

💛 Their “tantrums” seem more like meltdowns due to overwhelm, rather than power struggles to get their own way

💛 They are very bothered by tags on their clothes, wearing socks, cleaning their teeth, or certain foods or sounds 

💛They are highly creative & intuitive 

💛 They often struggle with big emotions (such as anger or anxiety) more than other children 

💛 Their beautiful heart reminds you of what’s most important

#ResilientLittleHearts 

.
.
.
.
.
.

#sensoryprocessingdisorder

node.text:
Highly sensitive children need to know that there isn’t anything wrong with them.⁣
⁣
They need to know that the way they experience the world is good, and beautiful, and true.⁣
⁣
They need to know that it's ok that they need empathetic support as they navigate fear & overwhelm.⁣
⁣
They need to know that who they are is a gift to this world 💛💛💛⁣
⁣
We are on mission to share this message with all the highly sensitive children in the world.⁣
⁣
Tag a friend who is raising a highly sensitive child 👇🏼
⁣
——————————————⁣
⁣
Our children’s book #TheBoyWhoStoodUpTall is about overcoming fear & finding courage, particularly for those with sensitive hearts. 
⁣
To get a copy for your home, classroom or homeschool library, the links are in our bio or IG stories @ResilientLittleHearts 
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on August 19, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of text that says 'Emotional literacy (knowing & naming emotions), is just as important for boys, as it is for girls. SARAHBOYD SARAH BOYD RESILIENT r'.

node.text:
For many, the previous decades in our culture have defined talking about emotions, as something that is just for women.

The impact of this, is that many boys have grown up not feeling comfortable with their feelings, or discovering appropriate expression for them.
When this occurs, it often leads to heightened aggressive expressions, increased mental health issues, & lower performance in school & work.

This is why, as we have an opportunity to cultivate health in a new generation, it is so important that we teach emotional literacy to BOTH boys & girls.

Emotional literacy is knowing, & being able to name, different emotional states.
It is feeling comfortable to talk about emotions.

As we teach emotional literacy in childhood by naming emotions, talking openly about feelings, & comforting our crying boys as much as our girls, we are laying the foundation for a healthier next generation… 💛💛💛

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on August 18, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of text that says 'No matter how frustrated, exhausted or heart-broken you feel, do not lose hope that there is goodness & light within your child. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT T'.

node.text:
Sometimes when we are navigating a particularly challenging season with our child, it can feel like there is no hope...

💛 Maybe your child is still chronically mis-behaving despite every positive thing you have tried

💛 Maybe your child has a personality that just rubs you the wrong way, leaving you constantly frustrated

💛 Maybe your child has special needs & you are exhausted from the constant patience required

It can feel so very discouraging...

In these moments, it can be very easy to make "closed door" meanings about your child - negative beliefs that remain unchallenged & form your opinion of who your child really is.

Without realizing it, we can create negative internal narratives about our child, that influences the way we show up with them.

And the thing is, our child can tell... They can tell if we have negative opinions about who they are as a person. They can tell if we have given up trying with them...

.
In these moments we have two choices -
1. To reframe the challenge from a positive perspective so that we gain empathy & understanding.

2. To practice patience: remembering that over time, many of the frustrations we experience with our child will change as their development continues

"No matter how frustrated, exhausted or heart-broken you feel, do not lose hope that there is goodness & light within your child." @sarahboyd

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Noticing emotions EMOTIONAL LITERACY Understanding emotions Naming emotions @ResilientLittleHearts'.

node.text:
Emotional literacy is one of the foundational building blocks for your child’s future mental & emotional health. 

Emotional literacy is made up of… 

💛 NOTICING EMOTIONS: being able to identify when they, or someone else, is feeling an emotion.

💛 NAMING EMOTIONS: being able to label each emotional state (eg. Happy, Sad, Angry, Scared). 

💛 UNDERSTANDING EMOTIONS: knowing the meaning of the main emotions, & how to manage them in healthy ways. 

To promote the development of emotional literacy in children, at home & in the classroom, you can: 

🍃 Practice naming different emotions as they arise 
🍃 Read books about characters experiencing different emotions 
🍃 Talk openly about feelings 
🍃 Use empathy in conflict resolution - “How do you think _______  might be feeling?” 
🍃 Use emotions check-ins - “How are you feeling today?”
🍃 Use emotional problem solving - “When we feel _________ what do you think we could do that would help us & others?” 

What are some of your favorite ways to teach emotional literacy to children? 👇🏼

#ResilientLittleHearts

#ResilientLittleHearts

Share your best tips below for connecting with a child who you’re struggling to connect with 👇🏼

#ResilientLittleHearts 

💛💛💛💛💛💛💛

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on July 15, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'You cannot create teachable moments with children, during emotional meltdowns. Connect, allow the emotions to pass, & then you can teach. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT'.

node.text:
When your child is highly emotional, they aren’t looking for rational advice or “teachable moments”.⁣
⁣
⁣
They are looking for LOVE and CONNECTION. ⁣
⁣
⁣
So sit with them, hug them, be with them 💛⁣
⁣
⁣
Then once they are no longer in an emotional state, you will be able to talk about a rational solution to the problem. ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts
